docs.lead_paragraph: A young man’s suicide highlights issues in the treatment of A.D.H.D., as youths fake symptoms to feed their addictions to potentially dangerous stimulants.

headline.seo: Concerns About A.D.H.D. Practices and Amphetamine Addiction
headline.main: Drowned in a Stream of Prescriptions
headline.print_headline: Drowned in a Stream of Prescriptions

docs.abstract: Suicide of Richard Fee, popular college class president and aspiring medical student, highlights failings in treatment of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder; conversations with Fee's friends and family reveal an intelligent and articulate young man who lied to doctors, physicians who issued hasty diagnoses, and psychiatrists who continued to prescribe potentially dangerous stimulants despite evidence of his growing addiction and psychiatric breakdown.
docs.snippet: A young man’s suicide highlights issues in the treatment of A.D.H.D., as youths fake symptoms to feed their addictions to potentially dangerous stimulants.

docs.lead_paragraph: The state has an unexpected $8.8 billion two years after it cut programs and services to meet a shortfall. But it is being held back by self-imposed caps.

headline.seo: Texas Has Plenty of Money, but Not to Spend
headline.main: Plenty of Money in State Coffers, but Not to Spend
headline.print_headline: Plenty of Money In State Coffers, But Not to Spend

docs.snippet: The state has an unexpected $8.8 billion two years after it cut programs and services to meet a shortfall. But it is being held back by self-imposed caps.

docs.lead_paragraph: Recent data present a strong case for baby boomers as the greatest victims of the recession and its grim aftermath.

headline.seo: Americans Closest to Retirement Were Hardest Hit by Recession
headline.main: In Hard Economy for All Ages, Older Isn’t Better ... It’s Brutal
headline.print_headline: In Hard Economy for All Ages, Older Isn’t Better ... It’s Brutal

docs.abstract: Labor Department's latest jobs snapshot along with other data present strong case for baby boomers being greatest victims of recession and its aftermath; Americans in their 50s and early 60s have lost most earning power of any age group, with their household incomes 10 percent below what they made when recovery began.
docs.snippet: Recent data present a strong case for baby boomers as the greatest victims of the recession and its grim aftermath.

docs.lead_paragraph: An economist suggests that so-called budget sequestration — government spending cuts — could actually help the nation’s economy, if the right kind of cuts are made.

headline.seo: Budget Sequestration: How to Do It Right
headline.main: Nips and Tucks and Big Budget Cuts
headline.print_headline: Nips, Tucks And Big Budget Cuts

docs.abstract: Tyler Cowen Economic View column suggests that impending budget sequestration--government spending cuts--could actually help nation’s economy; contends that most cuts should proceed on schedule, though with some restructuring along the way; calls for military and Medicare budget cuts.
docs.snippet: An economist suggests that so-called budget sequestration — government spending cuts — could actually help the nation’s economy, if the right kind of cuts are made.

docs.lead_paragraph: Millions of dependents may suffer because of the I.R.S.’s needlessly strict reading of the health care law.

headline.seo: A Cruel Blow to American Families
headline.main: A Cruel Blow to American Families
headline.print_headline: A Cruel Blow to American Families

docs.abstract: Editorial expresses disappointment at Internal Revenue Service's ruling on how to calculate affordability of health insurance offered by employers, which could leave millions of Americans with modest incomes unable to afford family coverage under their employers' health insurance and ineligible for subsidies to buy coverage elsewhere; notes that ruling stems from needlessly strict interpretation of Affordable Care Act.
docs.snippet: Millions of dependents may suffer because of the I.R.S.’s needlessly strict reading of the health care law.
